title: Competition calls confound bankers across the sector
text:
Any big bang inquiry, such as the ACCC’s examination of the mortgage pricing that was ordered by then-treasurer Scott Morrison in May 2017 and made its final report in December 2018, will need a tick from current Treasurer Josh Frydenberg.

And it’s understood that Frydenberg is more focused on ensuring credit is flowing to the housing sector just now, given the rather fragile state of economic growth.

Still, considering the ACCC got more funding in 2017 to set up a permanent financial services unit, we shouldn’t be surprised that chairman Rod Sims wants to do more.

The first point of unity from the two banking chiefs this column spoke with – on inquiry fatigue – is well made.

The sector argues that over the past five years there have been four big inquiries that have looked into competition, or at least touched on adjacent issues: David Murray’s Financial Systems Inquiry, which reported in 2014; the Productivity Commission’s look at competition in the Australian financial systems, which reported in August 2018; the aforementioned ACCC inquiry and the Hayne commission.

That the big banks have enough on their plates responding to these previous inquiries is not surprising. But it was the regional bank CEO who was most dreading the work involved in another inquiry.

Indeed, he suggested that these inquiries actually hurt competition in and of themselves, given the bigger banks could more easily absorb the cost and distraction required to formulate appropriate responses.

The second point – that regulators should be more worried about the quality of competition than the number of competitors – is more nuanced.

Advertisement

Sims told a parliamentary committee last week that “even though you've got some quite big players outside the big four, it's not clear that any of them are really displacing any of the big four or making serious inroads''.

But the view from within the banks is very different.

Our big four chief says the mortgage market – which is now really the only prize as the big four simplify themselves – is currently ultra-competitive and the majors are giving ground.

The statistics from the year to June 30 show that while the big four’s market share is still dominant at 75.1 per cent, this has retreated from 76.2 per cent.

This share has been mainly taken by the so-called challenger banks – led by Macquarie Bank, Members Equity Bank, AMP Bank and three foreign challengers – ING, HSBC and Citigroup – which have had their overall share rise by 70 basis points to 8.7 per cent.

Meanwhile, the non-bank sector’s market share has risen to 6.2 per cent from 5.8 per cent.

Perhaps more interesting is the momentum enjoyed by some of these challengers versus the big four.

As of June 30, the majors were increasing their mortgage books at 0.57 times the growth of the entire banking system, well down from 0.81 times a year earlier.

Advertisement

But the challengers are growing at 3.4 times the system, up from 2.06 times a year earlier. The non-banks are also growing at 2.85 times, up from 2.33.

There are some fascinating moves among the challenger cohort. For example, HSBC is growing at 12.16 times system, up from 4.75 times at June 30, 2018. And Macquarie is growing at 3.62 times, up from 2.51.

Obviously, these challengers’ loan books remain tiny compared with the big four. And Sims is right that it’s far too early to claim that any of them are making “serious inroads” into the market position of the big four, particularly given their huge customer bases.

But it does appear that the fight for new loans is intense – and that’s before any neobanks really get going, and big tech giants such as Apple and Amazon make the market forays that everyone expects over the longer term.

Our regional bank chief would also like to finally see some movement on the changes to capital rules that would call for regional banks to hold much higher levels of capital against their home loans than the big ones.

These changes were recommended by the Murray inquiry and rubber-stamped by the productivity inquiry, but there’s been little movement.

While the regional banks do concede their size does require them to hold more capital than the big banks, seeing this gap closed is much more important to them than yet another inquiry that might not hand down its findings until 2021.
description: The threat of yet another competition inquiry has big and small banks singing from the same hymn sheet as challenger banks gain momentum.
